prompt: Facts: The deceased, Paramjit Kaur, aged about 14/15 years, was a student.; The respondent, Gurmit Singh, was the Headmaster of the school where the deceased studied.; On the night between 11th and 12th September 1988, the deceased went to the house of the respondent.; When she did not return, her parents (PW4 Mohinder Singh and PW5 Pritam Kaur) searched for her.; They went to the respondent's house around midnight.; The respondent initially denied that the deceased was in his house.; Later, upon insistence, the respondent admitted she was inside but refused to open the door.; The parents sought help from neighbours and eventually the police (SI Amarjit Singh, PW9).; The police arrived, and after repeated requests, the respondent opened the door.; The deceased was found lying dead on a cot inside the respondent's house.; Post-mortem examination conducted by Dr. Ajit Singh Mann (PW1) revealed:;  - Cause of death: Asphyxia due to smothering.;  - Injuries on the private parts, torn hymen.;  - Presence of semen detected in vaginal swabs.; The respondent was charged under Sections 376 (Rape) and 302 (Murder) of the IPC.; The Trial Court acquitted the respondent, disbelieving the prosecution witnesses and medical evidence.; The State of Punjab appealed to the High Court of Punjab and Haryana.; The High Court reversed the acquittal and convicted the respondent under Sections 376 and 302 IPC, sentencing him to life imprisonment for murder and 10 years RI for rape (sentences concurrent).; The respondent (Gurmit Singh) appealed this conviction to the Supreme Court.; Supreme Court Observation: Noted the trial court's insensitivity and inappropriate handling of cross-examination regarding the victim's character, emphasizing the need for dignity and respect, especially in sexual assault cases.; Supreme Court Observation: Stressed that the testimony of a victim of sexual assault stands on par with an injured witness and does not require corroboration if found credible and reliable.; Supreme Court Observation: Found the medical evidence (post-mortem) strongly corroborated the prosecution case regarding both rape and murder (smothering). | IPC: Section 376 (Rape), Section 302 (Murder)
